title: Midgut Volvulus due to Malrotation
setup_script: “A 2-week-old infant presents with bilious vomiting and abdominal distension. Parents report the baby becoming increasingly lethargic. How would you proceed with this patient?”

dynamic_flow.reply: HR 170 bpm, RR 50/min, BP 70/40 mmHg, Temp 36.5 °C.
Distended, tender abdomen with visible peristalsis; bilious gastric aspirate present via NG tube.

dynamic_flow.trigger: If resident places NG tube and decompresses stomach
dynamic_flow.reply: 50 mL bilious fluid returns, abdomen slightly less tense.
Metabolic acidosis (pH 7.25), elevated lactate, electrolyte imbalances due to dehydration.
Non-specific bowel gas pattern; possible double bubble with paucity of distal gas.
Whirlpool sign of twisted mesentery around SMA.

dynamic_flow.trigger: If resident orders upper GI contrast study
dynamic_flow.reply: Corkscrew appearance of duodenum with abnormal position of ligament of Treitz, consistent with malrotation with volvulus.

dynamic_flow.trigger: If resident delays diagnostic studies and management
dynamic_flow.reply: Infant becomes increasingly hypotensive (BP 55/30), tachycardic (HR 190), and poorly responsive.

dynamic_flow.trigger: If resident initiates resuscitation with IV fluids and broad-spectrum antibiotics
dynamic_flow.reply: Improved perfusion; HR decreases to 160, BP rises to 80/45.

dynamic_flow.trigger: If resident consults pediatric surgery and proceeds with urgent laparotomy
dynamic_flow.reply: Ladd’s bands divided, counterclockwise detorsion performed, mesenteric base broadened, appendectomy completed.

dynamic_flow.trigger: If examiner asks resident to describe operative technique
dynamic_flow.reply: Resident should explain: counterclockwise detorsion of volvulus, division of Ladd’s bands, broadening of mesenteric base, placement of small intestine on right and colon on left, and appendectomy.

dynamic_flow.trigger: If operative findings show viable bowel only
dynamic_flow.reply: Bowel reperfuses after detorsion; abdomen closed primarily.

dynamic_flow.trigger: If operative findings show necrotic bowel
dynamic_flow.reply: Resection of gangrenous bowel performed; remaining length measured; abdomen left open if concern for borderline bowel viability.
Rapid progression to bowel necrosis, peritonitis, septic shock, and death.

dynamic_flow.trigger: If resident evaluates for associated anomalies
dynamic_flow.reply: Cardiac evaluation reveals a small VSD; no heterotaxy noted.
Monitors for bowel obstruction, short bowel syndrome if resection needed; ensures parental counseling and follow-up with pediatric surgery.

critical_decision_points: Recognition of bilious vomiting in a neonate as a surgical emergency
Ordering appropriate imaging (upper GI contrast study, ultrasound)
Prompt initiation of resuscitation and antibiotics
Urgent surgical intervention with Ladd’s procedure
Intraoperative decision-making (bowel viability, resection if necessary)

Your resuscitation and timely decision to proceed with laparotomy were appropriate. You communicated clearly with the surgical team.Areas for Improvement:Further improvement includes articulating the operative steps of the Ladd’s procedure in detail and addressing intraoperative decision-making when faced with necrotic bowel.
